Legal_Issue: Whether the PRRA officer's decision was based on erroneous findings of fact or disregarded material evidence
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed risk upon return to Mexico due to harassment; evidence considered pre-existing with no significant change in country conditions
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed as moot
Court_Ruling: Court refused to exercise discretion due to applicants' removal from Canada
Claimant_Status: Applicants with unsuccessful refugee claim and PRRA
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard requiring deference unless findings are perverse or capricious
Assessment_Factor: Pre-existing nature of evidence, lack of significant change in country conditions
Procedural_Issue: Case rendered moot by applicants' removal prior to judicial review
Evidence_Used: Applicants' evidence of harassment in Mexico
Application_Basis: Risk upon return to country of origin (Mexico)
Evidence_Assessed: Evidence dismissed as pre-existing, no new material evidence presented
Relief_Sought: Overturning of PRRA decision through judicial review
Governing_Rule: PRRA decisions reviewed on reasonableness standard
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of new or material evidence showing changed country conditions
Harm_Assessment: Risk of harassment upon return to Mexico
Cause_Description: Applicants sought judicial review after unsuccessful refugee claim and PRRA, alleging error in PRRA decision
Evidence_Handling: PRRA officer found evidence insufficient and pre-existing
Evidence_Issues: Failure to demonstrate significant change in circumstances or new risks
Jurisdictional_Issue: Mootness due to applicants' removal from Canada
Evidence_Assessment: Officer assessed evidence as not meeting threshold for risk upon return
Decision_Rationale: No basis for review post-removal; decision deemed moot
Decision_Making_Body: PRRA Officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient evidence of changed circumstances or ongoing risk
